Note to Persons Answering the Local Government Questionnaire.

This questionnaire is divided into four parts:

PART I: Statute Labour Districts and Local Improvement Districts before 1908.
PART II: Nine-Township Local Improvement Districts and Rural Municipalities after 1908.
PART III: Villages.
PART IV: Towns and Cities.

You may answer the parts dealing with the types of local government under which you have lived, and disregard the other sections. For example, if you came to Saskatchewan after 1908 and have always lived in a rural municipality you will answer only Part 2; if you came to a rural area before 1908 and in later years moved to a town, you probably will be able to answer Parts 1, 2 and 4.

Some of the questions are repeated in more than one part. In each case, the question is to be answered in relation to the particular section in which it is included, and you may therefore need to answer the same question more than once, as it applies to different forms of local government under which you have lived.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

No. 10

Local Government.

PART I: STATUTE LABOUR DISTRICTS AND LOCAL IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS BEFORE 1908.

1. In which of these (and during what years) did you live?

Statute Labour Districts (1 township in size, before 1903).

2. If you remember when the organization of districts was on a voluntary basis, tell whether they were popular or unpopular?

For what reasons? The Stanleyville District was formed in the year 1894.

3. Was the decision to make them compulsory popular with the residents?

There were very few social functions as there were very few people residing in the district.

4. What arguments were used to justify the compulsion?

5. What objections to compulsion were raised?

Not to my knowledge.

6. Ratepayers meetings.
   - how many usually attended? Usually light or ten ratepayers attended the meeting.
   - what took place, and what was the order of business?
     School and municipal affairs was order of the business.
   - was there much discussion or argument? On what subjects?
     At times there were many acerbic hot arguments over school affairs.

7. Overseer.
   - was there much competition for this position? Not very much competition.
   - what was the regular occupation of the overseer? Full charge of school affairs.
   - was he considered efficient? Yes.
   - was he given a free hand in supervising district affairs? Yes.

Did he do much of the work himself?

8. Activities
   - what were considered the most important activities of the district (list in order of importance)?
     Church services were in order for the summertime. Where we made our own homemade ice cream with several hand freezers of one gallon size or more and served a full course meal.
   - was there general agreement that these activities be carried on? Yes.

At Christmas time presents, school concerts were in order at the school and Christmas tree where gifts were presented to the children.

Baseball equipment was all the district had for amusement. This was kept pretty well in the district.

PART II: NINE-TOWNSHIP LOCAL IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS AND RURAL MUNICIPALITIES (after 1908)

1. During what years did you live in a nine township L.I.D.? (Give numbers or names)

a nine township R.M.?

2. Did the people in your community like this form of organization better than the smaller units in existence before 1908?

For what reasons?

3. Describe ratepayers meetings, telling how many attended, what took place at meetings, which subjects caused the most discussion, and any differences noticed from meetings of earlier years.

4. Was there much competition for election to positions of reeve and councillor? Yes.

Were they regarded as positions of some honor, or just a "chore" that someone had to do? I think regarded as an honor as well as a chore

5. Were people generally satisfied with the way local affairs were managed by the reeve and council? They seemed to be known alternative.

If not, for what reasons?

Did people think that relatives and friends of council members received special favors? If so, of what kind?

Dear Miss Eager,

I am enclosing a questionnaire which was handed to me by my son Gordon who is a member of the Rural Municipality of Elmo No. 154, some time ago, and mislaid. Being an old pioneer, he thought I could fill it out better than he could, but I am unable to answer many of the questions and thought it would be better if I wrote a letter telling a little of what I know of local government activities in the early years, even before the Province was formed.

I came to Winnipeg from Ontario in April of 1892, and in July joined a Survey Party when we came on the Railway as far as we could, which was Red River Carts over the old trails as far as the Morden District as it is now known where we subdivided 14 Townships into Sections until Nov. 10th when we returned over the trails to South Qu'Appelle, or Troy, where we boarded the train for Winnipeg. I returned to Ontario in 1883, and with my Father came back to the West in the spring of 1884 to homestead, which we did in the Pheasant Forks district, 40 miles north of the C.P. Railway here, and now the Duff district. We farmed there for 15 years and then moved in 1897 to a farm near to Grenfell, to be near the Railway, where I farmed until retiring in 1927. During the 42 years we were on the Homesteads our lands were not taxed at all. Some School Districts were formed in that part, in which we were not included.

At Grenfell we were in a Statute Labor District, and done one day's work a year on the roads, for each quarter section we owned with a man and team. We paid taxes in cash to the Town School District. A change came in 1905 when the Province was formed. We were then in a nine-township Local Improvement District, for one or two years when by a vote of the ratepayers they were changed over to a Municipality. After a Council was formed in 1905 the Municipal taxes were collected in cash, and they also collected the School TAXES. I was elected by acclamation to serve on the first Council in 1905, and continued as Councillor till 1923 when I became Reeve and served as such for 2 years. I was away in England for a visit at the time of the Municipal Election and could not be elected, and never served again. Up to near the close of the last century, trails were in use mostly, and if bridges were required the Local Government would build them, and make the approaches. The settlers then began to fence pastures with barbed wire, for their horses and cattle which formerly had been herded and tethered. It was then that the road allowances had to be opened up, the sloughs filled, and deviations made around them and roads made through the scrub and bluffs. For many years or up to the 1st war, most of the settlers were willing and anxious to work on the roads, and in that way pay their taxes, or partly so, and then when money became more plentiful and labor scarce, it was very difficult to get roads built. It was then we got larger tools and road graders such as Fresno Scrapers which required four horses, and larger graders to be drawn by the gasolene tractors which were then coming in, and often not powerful enough. Then motor cars were coming in when better roads were wanted, and more graded roads which required road drags to keep them in shape. There was always a demand for more and better roads which were costly to build, especially in a rough country with sloughs, bluffs and hills, as we have over most of this Municipality, and the taxes were as high as most of the settlers were able to pay. We always had a long list of unpaid taxes. While I was in office our Council and Ratepayers meetings were always orderly. Some Councillors were not very capable as one might expect. When I was reeve I had occasion in one year to halt the roadwork in two divisions, because the appropriations had been exceeded by many hundreds of dollars in one division, and over two thousand in the other. In the latter division there was always an election for a councillor. I found that my experience in surveying was useful in my position as Councillor and as Reeve.

I think this is all that I need to write, and so will conclude.

Yours sincerely

Albert J Loveridge.

Dear Miss Eager,

I am enclosing a questionnaire which was handed to me by my son Gordon who lives in the Rural Municipality of Minapo No.154 near Elmo, Saskatchewan. Being an old pioneer, he thought I could fill it out better than he could, but I am unable to answer many of the questions and thought it would be better if I wrote a letter telling a little of what I knew of local government activities in the early years, even before the Province was formed.

I came to Winnipeg from Ontario in April of 1882, and in July joined a Survey Party when we came on the Railway as far as we could, which was Flat Creek (Manitoba). We then drove over 600 miles and even with Red River Carts over the 320 miles far as the Dundurn District as it is now known, where we subdivided 14 townships into Sections until Nov 23rd. Then we returned over the trail to South Qu'Appelle or Troy, where we boarded the train for Winnipeg. I returned to Ontario in 1885, and with my father came back to the West in the spring of 1886 to homestead, which we did in the Pheasant Forks district 40 miles north of the C.P.R. Railway here, and now the Duff district. We farmed there for 15 years and then moved in 1907 to a farm near to Grenfell, to be near the Railway, where I farmed until retiring in 1927. During the 15 years we were on the Homesteads our lands were not taxed at all, since School Districts were formed in that part, in which we were not included.

At Grenfell we were in a Statute Labor District, and some one days work a year on the roads, for each quarter section we owned, such a man and team. We paid taxes in cash to the Town School District. A change came in 1905 when the Province was formed, we were then in a nine-township Local Improvement District, for one or two years when by a vote of the Ratepayers the municipality was formed over the Municipality. After a Council was formed in 1905 the Municipal taxes were collected in cash, and they also collected the School TAXES. I was elected by acclamation to serve on the First Council in 1906, and continued as Councillor till 1923 when I became Reeve and served as such for 2 years. I was away in England for a visit at the time of the Municipal Election and could not be elected, and never served again. Up to near the close of the last century, trails were in use mostly, and if bridges were required the Local Government would build them and make the approaches. The settlers then began to fence pastures with barbed wire, for their horses and cattle which formerly had been herded and tethered. It was then that the road allowances had to be opened up, the sloughs filled, deviations made around them and roads made through the scrub and bluffs. For many years or up to the last war, most of the settlers were willing and anxious to work on the roads, and in that way pay their taxes or partly so, and then when money became more plentiful and labor scarce, it was very difficult to get roads built. It was then we got larger tools and road graders such as Fresno Scrapers which required four horses, and larger graders to be drawn by the gasoline tractors which were then coming in, and often not powerful enough. Then motor cars were coming in when better roads were wanted, and more graded roads which required road drags to keep them in shape. There was always a demand for more and better roads which were costly to build, especially in a rough country with sloughs, bluffs and hills, so we have over most of this Municipality, and the taxes were so high almost of the settlers were able to pay. We always had a long list of unpaid taxes. While I was in office our Council and Ratepayers meetings were always orderly. Some Councillors were not very capable as one might expect. When I was reeve I had occasion in one year to halt the roadwork in two divisions, because the appropriations had been exceeded by many hundreds of dollars in one division, and over two thousand in the other. In the latter division there was always an election for a councillor. I found that my experience in surveying was useful in my position as Councillor and as Reeve.

I think this is all that I need to write, and so will conclude.

Yours sincerely

Albert J Loveridge.

   Yes, but if there was any difference of opinion it came out at the annual meeting.

   No serious complaints.

I would very much like to do this questionnaire on Local Government but am afraid my information is too limited. My personal knowledge is of that which was known in the 1880s as the Primitive Methodist Colonization Company. This was a colonization company formed in 1882. This company received a grant of land from the Dominion government for colonization. This land was the first choice of colonization lands in the attractive Qu'Appelle Valley District. The company, without loss of time went to work to procure settlers. My parents, with four children were among the earliest settlers.

The writer was three at the time and am the oldest living member of the family who came from England in 1883. The local government was then under the P.M. Colonization Company, with the Rev. C.S. Willis as agent and secretary. Mr. A.J. Loveridge, another settler tells me that they were too busy building their homes to think much of local government.

The entries for homesteads were made through Mr. Willis, and if there were any taxes they were paid to him as Sec-Treas of the company.

The first record available now to me is of the formation of a Public School District in 1885. This was the Pheasant Forks Protestant School District #48, established by Ordinance #4 of 1885, passed November 18, of that year.

This was the school where I and brothers and sisters received our early education. A Mr. Mac Maholland was appointed returning officer for the election of trustees, and Mr. John Kenyon on a provisional Certificate was the first teacher.

The only taxes I remember being spoken of were School Taxes. However in 1897-8 I do remember some road work being done much to the disgust of all the early settlers, we liked the prairie trails better, they went direct to the place one wanted to go.

There must have been other municipal government as the years went by. After an absence of over forty-five years I went back to our homestead S.E. 2-28-9 and have paid the taxes since then; as follows:

Municipal Tax - Health Services - School Tax - Telephone Tax - Public Revenue $14.40 $14.40 $22.40 $2.25 $3.20

The Primitive Methodist Colonization Company seemed to just fade out. Have been unable to find any record of its end.

- if so, did this cause any difficulties?

EXHIBITION and GOLDEN JUBILEE CELEBRATION WELL ATTENDED

A large crowd was in attendance at the Wapella Agricultural Society's Fifty-Eighth Exhibition and Jubilee Celebration held last Thursday.

The day's programme started off with a parade of beautiful old decorated floats, bicycles, old machines, including an old steam engine, a separator, and a Model T with brass radiator front, both of which ran under their own power like new. The parade formed up at the school grounds at 10:30 A.M., and by 11:00 A.M. McCamick's Pipe Band and his Scottish dancers proceeded down 2nd Ave. to the Town Hall, then down Main Street to the Exhibition grounds where a full afternoon and evening's entertainment was provided. Main St. was lined on both sides with spectators to watch the colourful parade and the opinion of all was that it was the best parade seen outside of a city.

The float carrying a group was entered by the Wapella C.W.L. ladies who demonstrated in pioneer costumes the process of wool being clipped from the sheep to the finished product. A similar type of float with spinning wheel was entered by St. Andrews. The Central Grocer's parade came with a "Bonfire To The Pioneers" float of flowers, which was awarded second prize. Included in the parade were other well designed and outstanding floats, The Red Cross with nurses and characters portraying the world wide work of mercy, Sanderman's store, Stott's Hardware depicting old and modern ways of doing the family's washing, the North American Lumber Co.'s Ezy-built cottage, The Post Office, Kornblatt's float, Town Fire Brigade, The Commercial Hotel, Norman's Imperial Oil, Jubilee Choir floats, Jr. and Sr. who entertained with singing en-route. Also in the parade were pony riders and cowboys strumming guitars, not forgetting the "Gentleman Cop" clearing the way for the big machine, and all the little children's decorated bicycles.

A very pleasant part of our Golden Jubilee Celebration was the signing of the Guest Book by 137 of our Pioneers who have resided in the Province 50 years or more, or who were over 70 years of age. Tea and cakes were served to them from 2 to 4 p.m. in a special enclosure provided for them by the committee convened by Mr. F. Stott, and Mrs. Stott at the register.

Suitable gifts with engraved cards were presented to those who registered as follows: 1 Mr. and Mrs. Peter Maki, residing in Wapella or District; 2 Miss C. H. Coffinham, oldest lady resident born in Saskatchewan; 3 Mr. Harry McMillan, oldest gentleman born in Saskatchewan.

Mayor F. Giles gave the address of welcome to the Pioneers, followed by Mr. Lloyd Windrim, President of the Wapella Agriculture Society.

The Secretary of the Society informed us that the entry list to the Fair was larger than it had been for some years, over two thousand. The cattle class was down a little from previous years but there was an increase in the horse class, as in all other classes, and competition was keen. The judging of the Domestic and Fancy work exhibits was not completed until late afternoon which curtailed the time of viewing by the public.

A round of sports was continued all afternoon and evening, used all afternoon and evening, eight men's softball teams and eight men's teams competed for the ladies' prizes. The winners were: men's 1st Grenfell Gems, 2nd St. Andrews, 3rd Rocanville, 4th Moosomin, 2nd Grenfell, 3rd Welwyn. Another entertainment feature was the Scottish dancing by Piper D. J. McCormick's dancers.

Mr. G. Cole, the Hon. C. C. Williams, Minister of Labour, gave a brief former Wapella boy, and congratulated the address and congratulated the Agricultural Society on the celebration of its 50th anniversary since its association with this town and its activities. He related instances of his boyhood days here. He also congratulated the Wapella Jubilee Committee. Mr. Williams was accompanied by two of his daughters.

Lunches and supper were served in the rink by the Ladies' Committee, following which, a broom ball game was played between J. Starrett's "Oilers" and D. Currie's town team. This drew a large crowd and at the end of an exciting game the teams were deadlocked at 2 goals each and called it quits.

The Dominion shows were present on the grounds with their Ferris wheel, miniature cars and other novelties for the entertainment of all.

A grand display of fireworks closed the celebrations at the exhibition grounds. A dance was held later in the Town Hall.

Mr. Ronald Ede, cousin to the bride, and Mr. Charles Salonen, brother-in-law to the groom. The groom's gifts to his attendants were tie clips.

The reception was held in the church parlor for the immediate relatives and very close friends. The church parlor was decorated in pink and white flowers and wedding bells. The three tiered wedding cake, which was covered with gardenias in a miniature frame and decorated with silver leaves, was made by the bride's mother, and Miss Nora Ede. Mr. Howard Ede was toastmaster and after the toast the bride and groom responded. Pastor P.J. Koski led in grace and Miss Koski spoke a few words befitting the occasion.

The young couple plan an extended honeymoon trip, perhaps to Banff, and for going away the bride chose a beaguing with green accessories. Upon returning they will make their home on the groom's farm in Clayridge.

Tea and cakes were served to them from 2 to 4 p.m. in a special enclosure provided by the Ladies' Committee convened by Mr. F. Stott, and Mrs. Stott at the register.

Suitable gifts with engraved cards were presented to those who registered as follows: 1 Mr. and Mrs. Peter McCormick, the oldest couple residing in Wapella; 2 Miss C. Scott, oldest lady resident born in Saskatchewan; 3 Mr. Harry McMillan, oldest gentleman born in Saskatchewan.

Mayor F. Giles gave the address of welcome to the Pioneers, followed by Mr. Lloyd Windrim, President of the Wapella Agricultural Society.

The Secretary of the Society informed us that the entry list to the Fair was larger than it had been for some years, over two thousand. The cattle class was down a little from previous years but there was an increase in the horse class, as in all other classes, and competition was keen. The judging of the Domestic and Fancy work exhibits was not completed until late afternoon which curtailed the time of viewing by the public.

A round of sports was continued all afternoon and evening, Mr. Ronald Eds, cousin to the churches and bride, and Mr. Charles Salomon, having all joined well-known eyes. Mr. W. Sams of Ceremonies Master Ritter by invitation given by the reception of Mrs. Kooski at the Town Hall. A couple, Mr. and Mrs. G. Cole, accompanied by two of his daughters.

Luncheon and supper were served in the rink by the Ladies' Committee, following which, a broom ball game was played between J. Sharkey's "Oilers" and D. Currie's town team. This drew a large crowd and at the end of an exciting game the teams were deadlocked at 2 goals each and called it quits.

The Dominion shows were present on the grounds with their ferris wheel, miniature cars and other novelties for the entertainment of all.

A display of fireworks closed the celebrations at the exhibition grounds. A dance was held later in the Town Hall.

EXHIBITION and GOLDEN JUBILEE CELEBRATION WELL ATTENDED

A large crowd was in attendance at the Wapella Agricultural Society's Golden Jubilee Celebration held last Saturday.

The day's programme started early when the children were given a chance to ride on decorated floats, bicycles, tractors, etc., and steam engines and scrapers were displayed in the main street, both of which were very popular.

Then came the parade formed up at the Hotel Norman Imperial Oil, and proceeded down Main Ave., to the Exhibition grounds.

D. J. McCormick's band played as the procession proceeded along Main Street, to the Exhibition grounds where the entertainment was arranged.

The floats of both sides of the river were displayed with spectators to see them.

The float winning the prize was the Wapella C.W.L. ladies who demonstrated the value of sheep by means of wool being clipped from sheep.

A similar type of float with sheep was presented by Mrs. Andrews. The Central Grocer's float won the second prize.

OPEN LETTER

To the Burgess of Moosomin Union Hospital District

The Moosomin Union Hospital district has been asked to vote on the Sask. Hospital Services Plan to hold a vote in the entire Moosomin Union Hospital District regarding the admission of the Village of Fairlight into the area.

Briefly, the following is the outline of the plan to date:

Fairlight Village voted favorably last fall to come into the district. The results were gazetted by the Provincial Government. When the request for petition was circulated in the Village of Fairlight contesting—not the vote—but the fact that Fairlight was entering this Hospital District.

According to the Hospital Act, the next step is for Moosomin District is to hold a vote over the whole area to allow Fairlight to enter this Moosomin Union Hospital Area.

Your Hospital Board put no pressure on Fairlight to vote the original vote. The Board, however, does want Fairlight, and welcomes the people of Fairlight into the Hospital Area to serve many patients from Fairlight.

We have arranged for Burgesses to vote in any poll in the Hospital District. We have been allowed to reduce the number of polls to cut down the vote expenses.

You will be notified of any change in date.

We ask you to vote to allow the Village of Fairlight to enter this Moosomin Union Hospital Area.

Yours very truly,

Moosomin Union Hospital Board.

"Hymnspiration" Fitting End To Jubilee Celebration

In connection with the Jubilee celebrations, a Hymnspiration arranged by the Wapella Golden Jubilee Committee was held in the Town Hall on Sunday evening, July 31st. This was led by Amalgamated Choirs of Wapella.
EXHIBITION and GOLDEN JUBILEE CELEBRATION WELL ATTENDED

A large crowd was in attendance at the Exhibition and Golden Jubilee celebration held in Wapella. A large number of people attended with many coming from distant areas. The event was well organized by the Wapella Golden Jubilee Committee.

The day's programme started early with the opening of the exhibition hall. The hall was filled with various exhibits, including a display of vintage cars, a collection of old photographs, and a display of local artifacts. The exhibits were arranged in a way that it was easy to navigate through each section.

The first evening featured a fireworks display over the Wapella River. Wapella Mayor J.W. L. Johnson demonstrated how fireworks were used during the early days of settlement.

Mayor F. Giles gave the address followed by Mr. Lloyd Windrum, President of the Wapella Agricultural Society.

The Secretary of the Agricultural Society announced that the cattle show in the Fair was larger than last year. The cattle show included two thousand entries. The cattle class was divided into several categories, and there was an increase in the horse class, as all entries were judged.

The judging of the Demonstrators' Show was completed until late afternoon. The show was well attended and enjoyed by the public.

A round of sports was also included in the programme.

OPEN LETTER

To the Surgeons of the Minomin Union Hospital District

The Minomin Union Hospital district has been informed that the hospital trustees plan to hold a vote in the entire Minomin Union Hospital District regarding the withdrawal of the Village of Fairlight from the area. Below is the following statement:

Fairlight Village voted favorably last fall to leave the district. The result was guaranteed by the Provincial Government. We have been informed that a petition was circulated in the Village of Fairlight, counteracting the vote and requesting that the Village be re-entering this Hospital District.

According to the Hospital Act, the Minomin Union Hospital District is to hold a vote over the whole area to allow Fairlight to remain in the Minomin Union Hospital Area.

Your Hospital Board put no pressure on Fairlight before the original vote. They do not want Fairlight, and therefore the people of Fairlight into the hospital. We have many patients from Fairlight.

We do not wish to hold district meetings on this question. If necessary, you will receive another letter. Your information will be sent immediately prior to the vote. Contact your Hospital Board member or any question.

The vote is set for Friday August 15th. The polls are open from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. (CST). We have arranged for Butterpease to vote in any poll in the Hospital District. We have been allowed to reduce the number of polls to cut down the time required.

You will be notified of any changes if necessary.

We ask you to vote to allow the Village of Fairlight to enter this Minomin Union Hospital area.

Yours very truly,

Minomin Union Hospital Board.

1. In which of these (and during what years) did you live?
   As a youngster our family lived in a Local Improvement district.

2. If you remember when the organization of districts was on a voluntary basis, tell whether they were popular or unpopular?
   The organization of districts on a voluntary basis was popular because the farmers were too poor to pay their taxes in cash so they were allowed to work on the roads and keep them in repair in their particular area. Everyone could work out their taxes in this way.

3. Was the decision to make them compulsory popular with the residents?
   No, because as mentioned above farmers had no cash but could work their taxes out in labor.

4. What arguments were used to justify the compulsion? particularly during busy seasons - spring and fall and did not have time to do this extra work.

5. What objections to compulsion were raised?
   same reasons as above, but as time went on, the farmers found it easier to do the work in the district than pay their taxes in cash and so had to be contented to find time to do this extra compulsory work.

6. Ratepayers meetings.
   - how many usually attended? about 12 persons
   - what took place, and what was the order of business?
     conducted much the same as any ordinary business meeting today. Schools and roads were always the first and main consideration of these ratepayers in those days.

7. Overseer.
   - was there much competition for this position? not particularly - it was generally considered best to have someone who could read and write.
   - what was the regular occupation of the overseer?
     usually a farmer
   - was he considered efficient?
     for the most part, yes.
   - was he given a free hand in supervising district affairs?
     Yes - I believe so and was usually voted in by show of hands.
   - did he do much of the work himself?
     yes - did the same amount as the other farmers in the district.

   - what were considered the most important activities of the district (list in order of importance)?
     schools
     roads

9. Was there general agreement that these activities be carried on?
   Yes

10. What equipment did the district own?
    the district owned slusher scrapers which were pulled by the farmers' horses in the district, but farmers used their own plows in the road work.

11. Was it ever loaned to individuals? Yes the scrapers were loaned to individuals.

PART I: Statute Labour Districts and Local Improvement Districts before 1908.
PART II: Mine-Township Local Improvement Districts and Rural Municipalities after 1908.
PART III: Villages.
PART IV: Towns and Cities.

You may answer the parts dealing with the types of local government under which you have lived, and disregard the other sections. For example, if you came to Saskatchewan after 1908 and have always lived in a rural municipality you will answer only Part 2; if you came to a rural area before 1908 and in later years moved to a town, you probably will be able to answer Parts 1, 2 and 4.

Some of the questions are repeated in more than one part. In each case, the question is to be answered in relation to the particular section in which it is included, and you may therefore need to answer the same question more than once, as it applies to different forms of local government under which you have lived.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

PART I: STATUTE LABOUR DISTRICTS AND LOCAL IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS BEFORE 1908.

1. In which of these (and during what years) did you live?
   - 1893 to 1903.

   - It was very unpopular by the people who did not care about it.

4. What arguments were used to justify the compulsion?
   - They got a receipt for their taxes being paid.

5. What objections to compulsion were raised?
   - There was never any objection to the organization of statute labour districts; the trouble was that the ratepayers did not want to do the work out of taxes by voting.

PART III: VILLAGE.

1. In what villages (and during what years) have you lived?
   The Hamlet, Village and Town of Caronia from 1916 on.

2. Do you recall the formation of the village? Yes.
   If so, was there much excitement among the people over its formation or any particular notice given to this event?
   No.

3. If you lived in a R.M. or L.I.D. before moving to the village, what differences did you notice in the management of village affairs?
   We took some horses, cows and chickens with us so didn't notice so much difference. The Affairs of the village were managed more efficiently.

4. Was there much competition for the position of councillor? No.
   Was there usually a good turnout of voters for election of councillors? Yes.
   Was it generally considered that the council did a good job? Not always.

5. Was there any custom followed in the selection of overseer by council members (i.e., by rotation etc.)?
   No we decided who was the best man and voted him in to office.

In the conduct of village affairs, how did the importance of the overseer compare with that of the other councillors?
   The overseer was Peter, Peter, Blue man, Fireman, Inspector, etc. He was quite an important man who took his orders from the council.

6. What were the most important activities of the village council? (List in order of importance).
   1. Sanitation, see that every dwelling had a proper back house. Establish a drainage ground. No one would sell us land for one.
   2. Build sidewalks and roads and keep them clean.
   3. Typhoid fever.
   4. Smallpox.
   5. Everything as sanitary as possible.

Were these duties well performed? As well as could be.

7. Did property owners in the village think they were taxed unfairly compared with people living in the surrounding district and making use of village facilities? Yes, the taxes on a medium sized dwelling were as high as on a whole quarter section including buildings.
   Describe any efforts made in the village for the adoption of the single tax.
   We never had any in the village. During my term as Mayor in 1928 we tried it in Caronia.
   How successful were these efforts? Caronia.
   We did not go on with as it was not satisfactory.

8. Has there ever been much agitation or desire to have the village established as a town? It was established as a town in 1910, by necessity to get wider power.

PART IV: TOWNS AND CITIES.

1. In what towns or cities (and during what years) have you lived?
   In Banora since it became a town in 1910

2. If you remember its establishment as a town (or city), tell what you recall of any special notice given to the event.
   Remember the event very well. We just went through a typhoid fever and smallpox epidemic. We had to do a lot with raising wells, water and put in Water Works, costing over $100,000. We decided roads side walk etc. costing $5,000. Electric light and fire protection $35,000. All these improvements had to be made to make Banora healthy enough to live in. The assessed valuation of Banora was high enough to permit this expenditure but the Board did not have the power they had to become a town to get permission. Finally the Board could not secure a town and the Board lost its power.

What differences in the management of local affairs did you notice particularly compared with where you had lived previously?

When I came to Banora in 1905 there were no school districts organized. The Territorial Government was organizing the local Improvement Districts. The people had to organize the School Districts themselves. The population was predominantly Ukrainian. Practically none could write English. Very few could read or write in their own language. Jobs engaged by these people to be signers, voters, and organize their School Districts. These Ukrainian people Board ran their School District as well as their children and grandchildren are running their organization today.

PART III: VILLAGES.

1. In what villages (and during what years) have you lived?
   The hamlet, 1904 to 1908; village, 1908 to 1910; and town of Canora, from 1910 on.

2. Do you recall the formation of the village?
   Yes.
   If so, was there much excitement among the people over its formation or any particular notice given to this event?
   No.

3. If you lived in a R.M. or L.I.D. before moving to the village, what differences did you notice in the management of village affairs?
   We took some horses, cows and chickens with us so did not notice so much difference. The affairs of the village were managed more efficiently.

4. Was there much competition for the position of councillor?
   No.
   Was there usually a good turnout of voters for election of councillors?
   Yes.
   Was it generally considered that the council did a good job?
   Not always.

5. Was there any custom followed in the selection of overseer by council members (i.e., by rotation etc.)?
   No, we decided who was the best man and voted him into office.

6. What were the most important activities of the village council? (List in order of importance).
   1. Sanitation. See that every dwelling had a proper back house. Establish a nuisance ground. No one would sell us land for one.
   2. Build sidewalks and roads and keep them clean.
   3. In 1909 we had a typhoid fever and smallpox epidemic, kept everything as sanitary as possible.

   Were these duties well performed?
   As well as could be.

7. Did property owners in the village think they were taxed unfairly compared with people living in the surrounding district and making use of village facilities?
   Yes. Taxes on a medium sized dwelling were as high as on a whole quarter section including buildings.

   Describe any efforts made in the village for the adoption of the single tax.
   We never had any in the village. During my term as Mayor in 1928 we tried it in Canora.

   How successful were these efforts?
   We did not go on with it as it was not satisfactory.

8. Has there ever been much agitation or desire to have the village established as a town?
   It was established as a town in 1910 by necessity to get wider power.

PART IV: TOWNS AND CITIES.

1. In what towns or cities (and during what years) have you lived?
   In Canora since it became a town in 1910.

2. If you remember its establishment as a town (or city), tell what
   you recall of any special notice given to the event.
   I remember the event very well. We just passed through a typhoid fever and small pox epidemic. We had to do away with using well water and put in water works costing over $100,000. We needed roads, sidewalks, etc., costing $25,000. Electric lights and fire protection, $35,000. All these improvements had to be made to make Canora healthy enough to live in. The assessed value of Canora was high enough to permit the expenditure, but the village did not have the power we had to have become a town to get permission. Finally, the word came that we were a town and the people felt relieved.

3. What differences in the management of local affairs did you
   notice particularly compared with where you had lived previously?
   When I came to Canora in 1905 there were no school districts organized. The Territorial Government was organizing the Local Improvement districts. The people had to organize the School Districts themselves. The population was predominantly Ukrainian. Practically none could write English. Very few could read or write in their own language. I was engaged by these people to be Sec.-Treas., and organize their School Districts. The Ukrainian School Board ran their School District as well; as their children and grandchildren are running these organizations today.

4. Was there much competition for the position of mayor?
   Yes, sometimes.

5. What differences have you noticed in the services performed by
   the town (or city) recently as compared with earlier years?
   1. The Town Council employed the Town Policeman. Now the town is policed by the R.C.M.P.
   2. People from the Country Districts send their children to the Canora School to receive training in Grade 9 to 12 as Canora had always excellent School facilities. The School charged a tuition fee, which in many cases could not be collected but which made the taxes high for the rate payers. Now we have a larger unit which equalizes the taxes.

Do you think the changes are an improvement, or not?
   1. It certainly is a big improvement.
   2. The rate payers of Canora have to pay too high a mill rate compared with the country districts but Canora has now excellent educational facilities.

6. Has there ever been much complaint from property owners in the facilities of the town (or city) that they were taxed unfairly compared with people living in the surrounding district and making use of town (or city) facilities?
   Yes, especially in School matters.

Describe any efforts made for the adoption of the single tax.
   We tried it once but quit it as it was not satisfactory.

How successful were these efforts?
   We could not make it work.
